loans.name: Los Semilleros De Huepil Group

texts.es:
Este Banco comunal se llama “Los Semilleros de Huepil” está conformado por 19 emprendedores, quienes se dedican a diferentes rubros, entre los cuales se encuentran preparación de ensaladas, venta de joyas, venta de lencería, reparación de calzado, confección de ropa, peluquería, venta de alimentos congelados, entre otros negocios. Todos ellos pertenecientes a la ciudad de Chillán.
Jessica delegada del grupo del Banco comunal, quien en la foto se encuentra en la primera fila, en el lugar del medio, viste un vestido estampado con diferentes colores negro, amarillo, verde, fucsia, Calipso, usa su cabello suelto con flequillo y es de color caoba.
Ella se dedica a vender ropa nueva para dama. Desde hace un año aproximadamente.
Su mercadería la compra por internet o la compra directamente en el barrio Patronato, comprando modelos exclusivos.
Su horario de trabajo es flexible y sus clientes son conocidos y cercanos a su casa.
Con el crédito comprará ropa para dama, específicamente blusas.
Una de las metas para su negocio, es tener una boutique en la cual pueda ofrecer su mercadería de una manera más atractiva y cómoda para atraer más clientela.
Jessica vive junto a su marido y sus tres hijos de 13, 5 y 2 años de edad, uno de sus sueños a nivel personal es estudiar una carrera con alguna especialidad en idiomas.
Ella además está muy contenta, motivada y agradecida en participar de Fondo Esperanza, ya que le permitirá invertir en su negocio y aprender nuevas técnicas para mejorar la contabilidad de su negocio. Comenta que el grupo es muy comprometido y que las reuniones son muy amenas. 
Chillán es una comuna de la zona centro sur de Chile. Su nombre significa “silla del sol” en mapudungun, idioma de nuestros indígenas mapuches. Chillán es conocida como “Cuna de la Patria” o “Tierra de Artistas”, debido a que en la ciudad han nacido destacados personajes de la historia de Chile, como por ejemplo el conocido pianista Claudio Arrau.
texts.en:
This communal bank, called Los Semilleros de Huepil, is made up of 19 entrepreneurs who work in different areas, including salad preparation, jewelry sales, lingerie sales, shoe repair, tailoring, hairdressing, and frozen food sales, among other businesses.  All of them are in the city of Chillán.

Jessica is the delegate of the communal bank group.  In the photo she is in the middle of the front row, wearing a Calypso dress printed with different colors, black, yellow, green, fuchsia.  She wears her mahogany-colored hair loose with bangs.

She has worked selling new clothing for women for approximately a year.  She buys her merchandise on the Internet or directly in her Patronato neighborhood, buying exclusive styles.  Her work schedule is flexible and her customers are acquaintances and close to her house.

With the loan she will buy women's clothing, specifically blouses.

One of her goals for her business is to have a boutique in which she can offer her merchandise in a more attractive and comfortable way, to attract more customers.

Jessica lives with her husband and three children, ages 13, 5, and 2.  One of her personal dreams is to study some field with a specialization in languages.

In addition, she is very happy, motivated, and grateful to participate in Fondo Esperanza because it will allow her to invest in her business and learn new techniques to improve the accounting in her business.  She comments that the group is very committed and the meetings enjoyable.

Chillán is a village in the south-central part of Chile. The name means "Chair of the Sun" in Mapudungun, the language of our indigenous Mapuche.  Chillán is known as the "Birthplace of the Country" or "Land of the Artists" because in this region many of the great figures of Chilean history were born, such as, for example, the well-known pianist Claudio Arrau.

loans.use: to buy women's clothing, specifically blouses.

loans.name: Alba Liliana

texts.en:
In my region I am known as Albita. For three years I have been dedicated to selling maiz tortillas that I prepare them in my house.

I sell tortillas in the mornin and late and night. I have really faithful customers because the tortilla is a necessary part of the diet in this region.

For a few months I have begun to sell grains as frijoles and rice and the sales have been promising. I would like the loan to help me sell more of this new product.

loans.use: Compra de harina de maiz, cal y leña.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther operates a provisions store and sells sauce pans as well. The TEACH lending program has improved her knowledge in trading through the Kraban Support Foundation. She needs a Kiva loan of $850 to expand her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Enakhon

texts.en:
Enakhon was born in 1941. She started receiving loans in February, 2006. In spite of her age, she works to raise her granddaughter, whom she supports. Sometimes her granddaughter assistes her in the trade.

K. Enakhon trades children clothes and shoes in the open-air market. Because she does not have a regular trading place, she has to go to the district market and trade there. Her day starts with preparing food for her grandchild and then going to the market to trade, which is located 15 km from her home. Her assortment of goods is not large, but it is enough to make a living.

At present she needs $500 to equip her trading place with a light tent, thus improving her trading conditions. This will make it possible to earn additional profit and improve the food for her family.

K.’s granddaughter is in the photo.

loans.use: Improve trading conditions

loans.name: Ángela

texts.es:
Business Description

Angela sells water bottles and soda to residences. She started this business with the help of her brother who lent her start-up money. Right now she not only delivers water to residences but she also delivers to local shops and restaurants.

Loan Use

Angela intends to use the loan to purchase soda and water bottles at wholesale. With the profits she expects to attain, she will achieve one of her life’s goals: the improvement of her home.

Personal Information

She is 50 years old and lives with a daughter who is a single mother. Her principal goal is to build her house with quality materials and secure a great education for her grandchild.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Descripción del Negocio

Ángela se dedica a la venta de botellones de agua y gaseosas a domicilio. Este negocio lo inicio con la ayuda de su hermano quien le presto el capital para emprender el negocio. Actualmente no solo entrega el agua a domicilio sino que además entrega a tiendas y restaurantes de la zona.

Uso del Préstamo

Ángela usara el préstamo para comprar las gaseosas y botellones de agua al por mayor pues con las ganancias que esta segura obtendrá va a mejorar su vivienda que es uno de los objetivos que se ha planteado.

Información Personal

Ella tiene 50 años, su vivienda es mixta vive con una hija que es madre soltera. Su principal meta es construir su casa de mejores materiales que los de ahora y asegurar una buena educación para su nieto.

loans.use: Purchase beverages at wholesale

loans.name: Osman

texts.en: Osman lives in Khachmaz town, and is single. This 23-year-old man sells home products. Now he needs a loan of $825 to buy more home products and to increase the range of goods.

loans.use: To increase the range of goods

loans.name: Saydullo

texts.ru:
Saydullo M., 42, is married and has 4 children. For 6 years, he has been selling spare parts for cars, tractors and other mechanisms. For that, Saydullo rents a spot at the “Nikhi” market in Kurgan-Tube. Saydullo plans to use this loan to purchase spare parts in Dushanbe. With your help, Saydullo will be able to offer spare parts to the local farmers and save them a lot of time and money. Saydullo plans to repay this loan in 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Махмудов Саъдулло, возраст – 42 года, образование средне-техническое, женат, имеет 4 детей. Клиент в течение 6 лет занимается продажей запчастей для таркторов, автомобилей и других механизмов. Для этого клиент арендуют торговую точку на рынке «НИХИ» города Курган-Тюбе. На полученный кредит клиент планирует приобрести в городе Душанбе запчасти и продавать их в Курган-Тюбе. В связи с началом посевного сезона местные фермы будут иметь возможность приобрести необходимые запчасти для своей сельхоз техники в городе Курган-Тюбе, что намного съэкономит их время и денежные средства, так как им не надо будет ехать за запчастями в город Душанбе Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of spare parts

loans.name: Mehri

texts.ru:
Mehri started her business 5 years ago when she lost her job and was forced to work at the agricultural market and to sell cottonseed oil. Mehri’s son and her neighbor bring her products to sell from the city. Her neighbor helped her to start her business. She plans to expand her business as the oil is in high demand in her area.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Началасвой бизнес 5 лет назад, когда она потеряла работу и вынуждена была работать на сельском рынке и продавать хлопковое масло. Товар для подажи, привозят из города сосед и ее сын , в начинании бизнеса ей помог сосед, которым она до сех пор занимается. Она планирует расширить свой бизнес, так как масло которое она продает, продается очень хорошо в ее местности.

loans.use: Sale of Cottonseed Oil

loans.name: Sara

texts.es:
Sara has been married for 5 years. Her husband works as a public transportation driver. They have 2 children. She dedicates herself to clothing sales. She gets the merchandise from the city of Clorinda in Argentina - a city that borders our country and can be reached within minutes.

She has been a long client and has very good payment behavior. Previously, she had no commercial references. La Fundación was the first institution that provided her a loan and thanks to it, she was able to uplift her business.

Currently, she seeks a new loan which will be used to buy clothing at wholesale and at greater discounts.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Translator.

La Sra. Sara esta casada hace 5 años, su marido trabaja como chofer de un transporte público, tiene 2 hijos. Ella se dedica a vender ropas, y las compras de los mismos la realiza en la ciudad de Clorinda – Argentina, ciudad que limita con nuestro país y se encuentra a pocos minutos.

Es una clienta muy antigua y con muy buena moral de pago. Anteriormente no tenia referencias comerciales y La Fundación fue la primera institución que le brindo un crédito, y gracias a eso ella pudo levantar su negocio.

Ella hoy solicita un nuevo crédito con lo que podrá adquirir ropas en mayores cantidades y así obtener mayores descuentos.

loans.use: to buy t-shirts, pants, skirts, blouses, shorts, and clothing for kids

loans.name: Nalukolongo 1(A) Group

texts.en: Sharifah is 32 years old and married with four children. She sells raw foods in the market. With the extra business profits, she intends to build a residential house and also start a cultivation business. Caroline and Joyce both have retail shop businesses and intend to use the loan to increase stock. Ruth makes and sells candles and wants to expand the business.

loans.use: To expand the banana business

loans.name: Constatina's Group

texts.en:
Constatina and Neli have been members of the community bank “Ollantay II” for thirteen and eight years respectively. In that time they have learned about responsibility and punctuality. They have learned how to treat their children and have healthy relationships with their family.

Constatina is 42 years old. She lives with her partner and three daughters. Constatina has a small store where she sells food staples such as flour, sugar, and rice. She opened her store seven months ago. Before opening her store she worked as an artisan with her brother. When he passed away she found herself unable to continue in that line of work.

Neli is 35 years old. She is married and has two children. Neli sells wood products for building. In addition, she makes and sells furniture. She has been running this business for seventeen years. She travels eight hours by poor roads to the jungle area to buy wood two to three times per month. She also recently used her savings to buy a van, which is used to transport people between towns in the region.

Constatina and Neli need loans of 600, and 1600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to add a public telephone to their store, and to buy more wood.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest-earning savings account each associate has. Both Constatina and Neli have recently used their savings to open their store and to buy a van. Their dreams are to continue moving forward, and that their children will have a better life.

loans.use: Constatina and Neli need loans of 600 and 1600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to add a public telephone to their store and to buy more wood.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima, age 27, is the single parent of a 7-year-old girl. Since 2004, she has made a living selling clothing and cosmetics door to door from 7:30 a.m. to 8:30 p.m. From her sales, she makes a monthly profit of about $620.

In the past, Halima used a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy more clothing to sell. Having paid it back successfully, she hopes to take a new loan to once again buy more clothing.

Halima is a member of a loan group known as Tiger, which has 25 members who hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell door to door

loans.name: Semilla Group

texts.es:
Sale of garments is the main activity of this group of fifteen women who wish to improve their standard of living. Thanks to Pro-Mujer ("Pro-woman"), they are achieving their aim. Early morning every fortnight, they travel to Iquique (Chile) and Desaguadero (at the border with Peru) to buy clothes at wholesale prices. They are then offered for sale at major markets in La Paz.

They need capital to purchase or rent a more appropriate and permanent retail site from which to sell their goods. This would increase their income and would allow them to save for the future of their families.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

El comercio de ropa es la principal actividad de quince mujeres deseosas de mejorar su estilo de vida, que gracias a Pro-mujer lo están consiguiendo. Muy temprano cada quince días, realizan viajes a Iquique (chile), y al Desaguadero (frontera con Perú), de éstos lugares compran ropa al por mayor para luego comercializarla en los principales mercados de La Paz, Necesitan capital para poder comprar puestos fijos y/o alquilar ambientes más adecuados para ofrecer sus productos de esta manera generar mayores ingresos que les permita ahorrar para el futura de sus familias.

loans.use: Capital requirement for the acquisition of permanent retail site

loans.name: Gara United Group

texts.en:
Mohamed T. is 36 years old and married with two children. With his previous loan from Kiva, Mohamed expanded his business by producing and selling tye and dye materials in addition to selling sewing supplies.

As a group leader, he was able to work with other members cooperatively and they were able to complete all their repayments on time.

Hawa Bangural owns a small grocery in the market and would like to expand the business. Mariatu S. sells fresh fish in the same market. She would like to increase her stock and build her own capital.

They are therefore requesting a loan of Le.4,000000 ($US1,200).

loans.use: To purchase clothing and sewing supplies, fish and groceries.

loans.name: Aku Viviane

texts.fr:
Unmarried with one child, Miss Aku Viviane S. was born on 3 August 1983 in Yikpa Dzigbé in the Prefecture of Daye in the plateau region. In 2002 she opened a store selling basic need goods in the Adidogomé district in Lomé. She has already benefited from one loan through WAGES and repaid it without incident.

This second loan she is asking for will allow her to buy 15 bags of rice and 20 boxes of laundry soap to supply her store "HORISON MAO."

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

Célibataire avec un enfant, Mademoiselle S. Aku Viviane est née le 03 août 1983 à Yikpa Dzigbé dans la préfecture de daye dans la région des plateaux. Elle a ouvert en 2002 un magasin de vente des produits de premières nécessités dans le quartier d’Adidogomé à Lomé. Elle a une fois bénéficié du crédit auprès de WAGES et a bien remboursé.

Ce second prêt qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’acheter 15 sacs de riz et 20 cartons de savon de lessive pour alimenter sa boutique « HORISON MAO ».

loans.use: To buy rice and laundry soap

loans.name: Finesse Group

texts.fr:
The Finesse group is made up of married women, mostly from polygamous households. Their average age is 28; each has, on average, two children. They live in the Médine neighborhood of the city of Sikasso, in the third economic region of Mali. These women buy and sell wax-printed fabric (highly prized in West Africa), food oils, potatoes, sweet potatoes, yams, and beauty products (creams, pomades, and baby powder), as well as various other commodities. Linked by family relations and by this business partnership, they decided to pursue their first loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. With this loan they intend to buy five units of wax-printed fabric, ten liters of oils, twenty sacks of yams, and ten cartons of beauty products. They typically buy their stock from wholesalers at the central market in Sikasso, as well as from peasants who grow fruits and vegetables in the surrounding areas. Then, they resell their commodities at their market stall. Most of their clients pay in cash, although sometimes they pay with credit. The clientele is principally female. They expect to turn a monthly profit of 22500 CFA francs, which will be used to pay the interest on their loan and to reinvest in their business. Each woman hopes to become a wholesaler of fabric or of fruits and vegetables.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer.

Le groupe Finesse es composé de femmes mariées vivant en générale dans des foyers polygames avec une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans, 2 enfants et résidant dans le quartier Médine de de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région économique du Mali) Ces femmes exercent le commerce de pagnes wax (tissus très prisé en Afrique de l’ouest), d’huiles de consommation , de patates douces, de pommes de terre, d’ignames, de produits de beauté (crèmes laits pommades et poudre pour enfant) et divers autres articles. Unies par relations de parenté et d’alliance, les femmes du groupe décidèrent d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur premier prêt. Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter 5 pièces de pagnes, 10 litres d’ huiles, 20 sacs d’ignames, 10 cartons de produits de beauté. Elles s’approvisionnent généralement au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso auprès des grossistes attitrés et dans les localités environantes auprès de paysans producteurs de fruits et légumes. Ensuite elles viennent revendre ces articles dans les quartiers de façon ambulante, dans les marchés avec une place fixe sous des hangars. Les ventes sont en majorité au comptant et quelques fois à crédit. La clientèle est composée essentiellement des femmes . Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 22.500FCFA, lequel sera utilisé pour payer les intêrets du prêt et investir le reste dans leurs activités. Chacune d’elle compte devenir une commerçante grossiste de tissus ou de fruits et légumes.

loans.use: Purchase of foodstuffs and beauty products

loans.name: Blanca Rita

texts.es:
Mrs. Blanca B. is 49 years old and a single mother of three. One of her children is a sophomore in high school, and the others are fully grown. Blanca would like to invest heavily in her business in order to create a steady income for her household. Her dream is to install a clothing store, though now she sells used clothing in the town of malpaisillo. Blanca also has a store where she sells household products such as rice, sugar, oil, beans, detergents, sodas, chicken, and other household products. She has been in the business for over 12 years, and the income helps her support her family. Blanca started her business as an alternative to just getting by, because she doesn't get any help from the children's father. Now that she has gone through many loan cycles with our institution, Blanca hopes that she can always count on our help to grow her business.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Blanca B., tiene 49 años de edad es soltera, tiene tres hijos, de los cuales uno esta a su cargo cursando el segundo año de secundaria, es madre soltera, su proposito es poder invertir fuertemente en su negocio de esta manera tener una fuente de ingresos para el hogar, su sueño es poder instalar una pulperia con venta de ropa, ya que actualmente ella se dedica al comercio de productos del hogar como es arroz, azucar, aceite, frijoles, detergentes, gaseosa, pollo y demas productos de consumo del hogar, teniendo tambien la venta de ropa usada actividad que lleva a cabo en el municipio de malpaisillo, ella tiene mas de doce años de ejercer dichos negocios y con los cuales a apoyado a sus hijos, dando inicio como una alternativa de subsistencia ya que no contaba con el apoyo del padre de sus hijos, en la actualidad tiene varios ciclos de trabajar con nuestra institucion esperando contar siempre con el apoyo nuestro para desarrollar su proyecto.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Gabriela Graciela

texts.es: La señra Gabriela es de familia humilde. Tiene un hijo pequeño, y junto a su esposo se dedican a la compra y venta de material de recicleje, para ello ya son propietarios de dos tiendas ubicadas en la zona más comercial de la ciudad de La Paz, es cliente atigua de la institución, trabajando con nosotros dos años y medio, por lo que los créditos que ha solicitado han representado una parte fundamental para el desarrollo económico de su pequeño negocio, es por tanto que cuenta con un buen historial creiticio.
texts.en:
Gabriela is from a humble family. She has a young son, and she and her husband are dedicated to the purchase and sale of recyclables. They own two stores located in the most commercial areas of the city of La Paz, Perú. Gabriela is a well-established client of the Emprender institution (Kiva partner), having worked with them for two and a half years. The loans that Gabriela has requested in the past have represented a fundamental part of the economic development of her small business, and she therefore has a good credit history.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase capital

loans.name: Yuryi

texts.en:
Yuryi is single. He has always dreamed of being self-employed and decided to apply his practical skills to launch his business manufacturing granite products. Yuryi started this enterprise a year and a half ago. His business has grown to be a very stable and competitive enterprise offering a wide selection of items and a flexible discount system for clients. Yuryi has over $3,000 in turnover capital. His net profit is about $400 a month.

Yuryi has an entrepreneurial mind that is always alive, active, constantly calculating and always on the lookout for the next big opportunity. His business is profitable and stable. However, Yuryi would like to press on and expand it even more. Today he is requesting a loan of 5,000 Grivnas to increase his stock of raw materials for further granite work and to meet the growing demand.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials

loans.name: Kamal

texts.en: Kamal is a 43 year old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh in southern suburbs of Lebanon. He owns a small grocery store. He requested a loan of $1000 to buy goods and to decorate its display window. It is his first time that he asked for a loan.

loans.use: Kamal wants the loan to purchase goods and decorate his display window

loans.name: Khursandoy

texts.en:
Khursandoy H. is a widow living in Penjikent, Tajikistan with her only son. Khursandoy runs a small business selling men’s shoes and clothing in the local market. She has been involved in this trade for 12 years. She recently moved her vending facility to a different location which has brought an increase in her sales.  Khursandoy has many loyal customers. She is very friendly and amiable with each client, thus Khursandoy has a unique talent of attracting new customers. Khursandoy purchases clothing wholesale every week. She is hoping to use the loan of $750 to purchase winter clothing and shoes for men. She hopes to see her venture grow big enough to afford to buy a new vending facility in the future.  

Tajikistan is one of the poorer of the 15 former Soviet republics, with a GDP per capita of less than $600. The civil war, which took place soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., severely damaged the already weak economic infrastructure and caused a sharp decline in agricultural production and the manufacturing sector.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  All of these factors have resulted in a severe lack of jobs and have forced hundreds of thousands to leave Tajikistan to find work in other countries, mostly in Russia.  While Tajikistan has experienced some economic growth since the end of the civil war, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty. 

IMON International's mission is to promote sustainable economic development and improved quality of life in Tajikistan by insuring reliable access to financial services for the economically active members of the population. IMON International has 8 branch offices throughout Tajikistan and their entrepreneurs work in many parts of the country's economic sector including trade, manufacturing, agriculture, and services. As of October 2008, IMON International had 27,802 active clients and a total portfolio of $28,405,549.  Approximately 44% of these clients are women and 65% are from rural areas.  To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy winter shoes and clothing for men for sale

loans.name: Héctor

texts.es:
El señor Héctor M. tiene ya mas de once años dedicándose a la elaboración y venta de tacos este negocio es su única fuente de ingresos, su familia depende totalmente de ello.
El local es semiabierto y desea realizarle mejoras para mayor comodidad de sus comensales y así tengan una mejor atención hacia ellos, al igual quiere invertir en el producto de venta; tener lo suficiente para trabajar.
texts.en:
Héctor M. has been making and selling tacos for more than 11 years. This business is his only source of income and his family depends on it completely. His stand is partially open and he would like to make some improvements so that his customers are more comfortable and he can give them better service. He would also like to invest in his product so that he has enough supplies to work with.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fix up his stand and buy supplies.

loans.name: Khann

texts.en: Mr. Khann K. is a farmer in Lvae village in Takeo province. He owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. He faces an obstacle because his field is infertile and he does not have enough money to hire laborers to work the field. In order to solve this problem, he decided to ask for a loan for these purposes. His wife, Mrs. Keo Nan, helps on the farm. Mr. K. is 45 years old and the father of two children who are both employed in a garment factory. His wife is shown with him in the picture.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work on the field

loans.name: Mustafonqul

texts.ru: Давлатов Мустафонкул проживает в городе Куляб. Работает в средней школе , учителем .Кроме того привозит книги из города Худжант, которые реализует на рынке"Саховат" . Кроме того рядом продает самбусу , выпекаемую его женой. Дело приносит доход , но теперь он планирует увеличить товарооборот, путем получения кредита. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 14 месяцев. Он женат и имеет троих детей.
texts.en:
Mustafonqul D. lives in the town of Kulyab. He is a high school teacher. He brings books from Hujant and sells them at the Sakhovat market. He also sells sambusa that his wife bakes. THe business is profitable but Mustafonqul would like to increase cash flow. Therefore he is applying for a loan that he would pay off within 14 months. Mustafonqul D. is married with three children.

Translated from Russian by Oksana Buranbaeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase cash flow

loans.name: Amadith

texts.es:
La señora Amadith, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Picota”, vive en la Av. Las Paz – Las Malvinas S/Nº, Distrito de Picota, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 48 años y es madre de 02 hijos, todos ya independientes.

Se inicio, con S/. 300.00 y fue motivada por su esposo, para emprender su negocio y empezó con un taller mecánico, en su propia casa; donde ella atendía a los clientes.

En la actualidad se dedica a la Venta de Repuestos asociados en un negocio familiar juntamente con su esposo e hijo mayor, su negocio se ubica en un ambiente acondicionado en su propia casa, siendo sus principales clientes los conductores de carros, moto taxis, moto lineales  y ciclistas de la localidad y pueblos cercanos.

Con el préstamo de S/2,500.00 a plazo de 06  meses, comprara más repuestos como focos y faros  de luz y  tubos de escape para diversos tipos de movilidad, barras telescópicas para motos, llantas.  

Ella, su esposo y su hijo  toman las decisiones en la compras y  ganancias de su negocio, se siente más segura al ofrecer sus productos, se considera una mujer luchadora, constante y responsable con el pago de sus cuotas.

Amadith, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Amadith belongs to the “Picota” Community Bank in the San Martín region of Peru. She is 48-years-old, lives with her husband and has two grown-up children.

With 300 soles and her husband’s encouragement, she started her own mechanics shop and served customers in her home.

She currently runs a family business together with her husband and eldest son, selling spare auto parts from a specially converted space in her home. Her principal customers are car, mototaxi and motorcycle drivers, and cyclists from her town and neighbouring areas.

With this loan of 2500 soles to be repaid in six months, she will purchase more spare parts including headlights and exhaust pipes for a variety of vehicles, telescopic rods for motorcycles, and tires.

Amadith makes all business decisions with her husband and son, and feels more confident in the products she sells. She considers herself a spirited woman, reliable and responsible with her repayments.

Amadith is very grateful to Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow not only as an entrepreneur but also as a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase spare auto parts such as headlights and exhaust pipes for a variety of vehicles.

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer M. is 32 years old and lives in the beautiful coastal town of Pandan, located in northern Antique Province. She has two daughters and one son, aged 6, 4, and 2 respectively. She is unmarried, but lives with her partner Jojit; he is a laborer.

Jennifer is a business-minded person who runs a sari-sari store, raises chickens, and grows and sells vegetables. "Sari-sari" is Tagalog for "various kinds" and the shops sell just that: an assortment of basic foodstuffs, beverages, and everyday commodities. Jennifer plans to use the money from this loan to buy inventory for her sari-sari store, and to buy chickens to raise.

Jennifer hopes to be able to further develop herself in dealing with others, grow her business, and wishes a bright future for her children.

loans.use: To purchase food, beverages and other inventory for a small variety store, and to buy baby chickens to raise

loans.name: La Amistad #2 Group

texts.es:
Foto de Izquierda a derecha: Ana Santiago C. R., Ivonne P. y Simona García.

El grupo solidario La Amistad #2, es originario de la comarca La Reforma perteneciente a la ciudad de Masaya, de forma general se dedican a la venta de frutas y verduras en el mercado municipal, ellas compran las cosechas en las comarcas vecinas y sacan el producto al mercado.

Las tres miembros tienen mucha confianza entre ellas, son vecinas y se unen para la compra de algunos productos y así logran mejores precios. 

Doña Ana Santiago C. una  mujer adulta, que su activad económica que es la compra y venta de Frutas y verduras en el mercado, tiene un puesto donde paga un pequeño impuesto durante la mañana y luego recorre todo el mercado ofreciendo sus productos.
Se propone pagar los créditos con mucha puntualidad y animar a las integrantes para salir adelante, ella es la coordinadora del grupo. Su meta es de mejorar su vivienda y dejarla como ella quiere, para cuando sea mayor tenga comodidades y con el crédito ella piensa seguir invirtiendo para tener mas clientes y mayores ventas.
Las integrantes expresan que han tenido buenas ganancias con los créditos obtenidos, estos los invierten en temporadas que saben que hay demanda y buen precio.
Doña Ivonne P.  se dedica a la elaboración de ropa como delantales, gabachas y ropa que personas de la comunidad le encargan, ella entrega a algunas personas que venden ambulante. Vive con sus dos hijos adolescentes, ella es madre soltera y mantiene los gastos del hogar con su trabajo.

Doña Simona se dedica a la venta de verduras, ella compra las frutas en la zona donde vive y algunas en el mercado. Sueña  con mejorar su vivienda para sus hijos y ella, es madre soltera y ha criado a sus hijos sola, son jóvenes y trabajan junto a ella en el mercado.
texts.en:
Photo, from left to right: Ana Santiago C. R., Ivonne P. and Simona García. The group "La Amistad #2 is originally from the La Reforma area of the city of Masaya. In general, the group is in the business of selling fruits and vegetables in the municipal market. The group members buy the crops in the neighboring areas and bring the products to the market. The three group members have a high level of trust among them, as they are neighbors and work together to buy some of the products in order to get better prices. Ana Santiago C. is a grown woman who buys and sells fruit and vegetables in the market. She has a small kiosk where she puts in time in the mornings and later she goes through the entire market offering her products. She intends to repay the loan punctually and to motivate the other group members to keep moving forward, as she is the coordinator of the group. Her goal is to make improvements to her home and to have it just the way she likes it so that when she is older she can be comfortable. She would like to invest this loan in order to get more clients and more sales. The group members state that they have seen good earnings from the loans they've obtained, which they have invested in seasons during which there is good demand and a good price. Ivonne P. makes clothes like aprons, "gabachas" (traditional aprons), and clothes ordered by people in her community and delivers to some people who sell door-to-door. She lives with her two teenage children, and she is a single mother supporting the expenses of her family with her work. Simona sells fruits and vegetables. She buys fruit in the area where she lives and some in the local markets. She dreams of improving her home for her children. She is a single mother and has raised her children alone. They are young and work with her in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fruit and vegetables to offer to clients (oranges, avocados, lemons, etc.)

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: Lilian S. is a married Tanzanian woman who operates a business selling fried and fresh fish at Yombo Vituka ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases wholesale fish direct from local fishermen at Ferry Fish Market and sells at retail prices to her customers. She uses her income to meet her family's daily needs and to help her business. She is requesting a loan so she can increase her inventory and her sales potential, which will help her better care for her family.

loans.use: To purchase goods for her business

loans.name: Haseeb

texts.en:
Haseeb is 48 years old and lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their four children. Haseeb sells oil and olives to all sorts of customers and has requested a loan of $700 USD from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase oil.

This is Haseeb's second loan cycle and he has always paid on time. His previous loan helped him improve his business. When Haseeb first started out, he had financial issues. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase oil to sell

loans.name: Ashurmad

texts.ru: Ашурмад Холов проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст 40 лет. Женат, имеет 2 детей. По специальности Ашурмад является "артистом". В данный момент ашурмад играет на свадебных мероприятиях. Этим видом деятельности занимается более 6 лет. Клиент просит кредит, чтобы отремонтировать свое оборудывание.
texts.en:
Ashurmad H. lives in the Hamadoni region. He is 40 years old, married and has two children. Ashurmad is an entertainer by profession. At this time Ashurmad plays instruments at wedding celebrations. He has been in this business for more than six years. The client is asking for a loan to repair his equipment.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To repair equipment

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en: Salamatu is a 32 year old, single young woman. She lives with her family at Sefwi, in the western region of Ghana. She is a food vendor and sells rice with gravy stew at the community where she lives. She started her operation about four years ago to take care of her home. Her food production is on a low scale because of inadequate funds to support her business. She wants to use the loan to buy more meat, vegetables and bags of rice to increase her efficiency to produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business and allow her to raise more income to support and finance her business growth. Currently she finances her food preparations with the sale of cosmetics.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, vegetables, meat and firewood, etc.

loans.name: Griselda Aida

texts.es: Griselda Aida M. R. de 34 años de edad reside en el municipio de Cojutepeque en el departamento de Cuscatlán junto a su esposo y sus tres hijas aun menores de edad. Griselda tiene un taller de fabricación de zapatos, donde elabora variedad de estilos en sandalias para dama, para después ser distribuidas a los alrededores de Cojutepeque. El negocio de Griselda tiene ya 20 años a flote y su deseo es seguir expandiendo la distribución de sus zapatos para la capital del país es por eso que Griselda solicita un crédito para la compra de materia prima para la producción de zapatos que le permita tener una mayor cantidad ya elaborados.
texts.en:
Griselda Aida M. R. is 34 years old and lives in the municipality of Cojutepeque, department of Cuscatlán, along with her husband and her three young daughters. Griselda has a shoemaking shop where she makes a variety of styles of women's sandals to later be distributed to the areas surrounding her town. She has had the business for 20 years, and her wish is to keep expanding the distribution to the country's capital. Griselda is requesting the loan so she can purchase production supplies that will allow to produce a larger quantity of products.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase raw materials to make shoes

loans.name: Harriet's Group

texts.en:
N. Harriet is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a married lady with 4 children, all in school, as she cares for orphans. She has a tailoring business that she has had for 15 years though on a small scale. Her main challenge is the competition from fellow workers and amidst all that, she is able to make 150,000/= worth of profits.

Harriet is a very friendly person and easy to talk to, yet very serious with what she does. She hopes to become a wholesaler of the clothes she makes and also build a residential house for her children. She is happy that together with her husband, she is able to educate her children using her profits. This time, she hopes to increase the capital in her business so that she will be able to make profit and put aside savings for caring for the children and business expansion.

loans.use: Clothing materials for the tailoring business

loans.name: Nahomi Group

texts.es: El grupo Nahomi está formado por Doña Faviola Robleto R., Jamileth G., María Engracia S. y Mirian del Carmen R.
texts.en: Faviola Robleto R., Jamileth G., María Engracia S., and Mirian del Carmen R.

loans.use: Buy cosmetics and other products

loans.name: Alegria Group

texts.es: El grupo “Alegría” esta representado por la señora Hilda y conformado por 18 miembros las cuales son socias dinámicas puesto que desean realizar actividades para confraternizar y unirse mas como grupo; las señoras tienen una amistad desde hace mucho tiempo ya que se conocen de sus actividades comerciales y son vecinas del barrio. En general las socias desempeñan diferentes tipos de actividades comerciales y de servicio como: salón de belleza, tienda de abarrotes, venta de comida y venta de cosméticos  y en cuanto los socios podemos mencionar un mecánico y otro presta servicios de limpieza una mayoría de sus actividades están en sus propios domicilios y otros son ambulantes.  Dentro del entorno competitivo podemos mencionar que las socias son personas con experiencia y saben como salir adelante con su trabajo y empeño. El crédito esta destinado a la compra de mercadería para surtir sus tiendas, compra de material de trabajo, insumos en mayor cantidad, las promotoras de cosméticos aprovecharon las ofertas para la adquisición de mercadería abajo precio. Dentro de sus expectativas están el tener tiendas mas grandes para poder genera mas ingresos y ser mas independientes económicamente, en cuanto a sus experiencias crediticias algunas solicitaron crédito anteriormente con otras entidades financieras por lo que cuentan con experiencia en grupos solidarios, en cuanto a a la experiencia en Agrocapital van cursando su primer ciclo con grandes expectativas de crecimiento.
texts.en:
The group “Alegría” (Joy) is led by Sra. Hilda and consists of 18 dynamic members who wish to participate in activities that will bring them closer as a group. The women of the group have been friends for a long time and know each other through their business activities and because they live in the same neighborhood. Most of the members have various retail and service businesses such as beauty salons, grocery stores, food establishments, and cosmetic sales. We can mention that one member is a mechanic, while another one provides cleaning services. Most of the members have their own locations while others travel door-to-door. It should be mentioned that the members are experienced and know how to cope in a competitive environment.

This loan will be used to buy merchandise to stock their stores, acquire supplies at wholesale, and obtain discounted cosmetics through promotional offers so that the members can take advantage of lower costs. Their expectations for the future are to have larger stores so that they can generate more revenues and be more financially independent. Regarding their previous credit experience, they have worked with solidarity group loans at other financial institutions. They are participating in their first loan cycle with Fundación Agrocapital and have high expectations to continue growing.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Ibaba

texts.en:
Ibaba R. is 20 years old and married to a businessman. They have two school-aged children. Ibaba is currently in the business of selling maize flour, and is requesting a loan to purchase beans and rice to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a motorbike for transporting her goods to the store.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth A. is from the village of P-Bonifacio, Lugait, Misamis Oriental. She is 52 years old, is married, and has three adult children. Elizabeth owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling specialty food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In October 2009, Elizabeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Luchando Contra La Pobreza Groups 1 And 2

texts.en:
Severina is the group coordinator for Banco de Esperanza (Bank of Hope) Luchando Contra La Pobreza (Fighting Against Poverty).  Her story is representative of the others in her group and more generally of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients. Severina lives in a rural and mountainous area near Puerto Plata.  Her community has unreliable access to running water (not potable) and electricity.  She is a single mother and lives with her four children. 

Severina sells food, fruit and gasoline to others in her community.  She has four years of experience with her business and this will be her fifth loan with Esperanza. She plans to use this loan to purchase meat (ham and chicken) and fuel to sell in her market. She wants to continue to grow her business more and more each day so that she can provide for her family.  Since becoming an Esperanza client, she has learned how to make good investments with her money and to think about the future.  She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: Meat (ham and chicken) and fuel

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta has been engaged in the piggery business for two years. She purchases hogs and raises them in her pigpen situated at the back of their house. She also raises native pigs, which are black in color.  Violeta is requesting a loan of PHP6,000 that she needs to purchase medicine and a feed supply for her hogs because they can consume at least ten kilos of feed a day.  She hopes that her request will be granted for her business to grow and support the needs of their family. 

Violeta is already a widow and left with six children. Most of them are still studying.  Together with her children, they live a simple life in the village of Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela.

loans.use: To purchase medicine and feed for her hogs

loans.name: Dominga

texts.es:
Dominga tiene 44 años de edad, es soltera y vive junto a su madre y dos hermanos en el caserío Hornitos, distrito de Mórrope, ubicado a 45 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Durante casi tosa su vida se ha dedicado a criar animales en casa de su madre y desde hace tres años empezó a comercializarlos en la ciudad de Chiclayo. Ella cría pavos, patos, cuyes y carneros. Usualmente viaja dos veces por semana a la ciudad para ofrecerlos en venta. 

Dominga nos cuenta que la demanda por los animales que ofrece ha ido creciendo pero que los animales que posee no son suficientes por lo que se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por pirmera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles para invertirlos en la compra de animales para ampliar su negocio y satisfacer a sus clientes.

Su más grande anhelo es hacer crecer su negocio y con las ganancias que obtenga darle a su madre una mejor calidad de vida. Ella es una mujer alegre, responsable y muy entregada a su familia y a su trabajo.
texts.en:
Dominga, 44, is single and lives with her mother and two brothers in the Hornitos settlement, Mórrope district, which is 45 minutes away from the city of Chiclayo. During most of her life she has raised small farm animals in her mother's house and three years ago began to sell them in the city of Chiclayo. She raises turkeys, ducks, guinea pigs, and mutton. She usually travels to the city twice a week to sell them. Dominga tells us that demand for her animals has been growing but that she does not have enough animals to meet it. For this reason she has called upon Edpyme Alternativa for the first time asking for a 1000 new sol loan to buy more animals so that her business will expand and she can meet her customers' demand. Her greatest wish is to see her business grow and to use her profits to be able to give her mother a better quality of life. She is a cheerful, responsible woman who is very dedicated to her family and to her work.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy animals to sell.

loans.name: Luz

texts.es:
Luz tiene 22 años, es madre de un hijo que tiene 9 meses y vive junto a su pareja, quien es trabajador independiente, y con su hermana en su casa propia.

Desde hace 2 años tiene una pequeña bodega en su vivienda, donde vende abarrotes, comestibles de primera necesidad y bebidas. Luz atiende durante todo el día y le va muy bien porque se encuentra en una zona transitada y concurrida de su localidad.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es dar una buena atención a sus clientes, y sentirse activa es lo más importante para ella. A su vez, le es rentable porque sus productos se venden a diario y cuenta con clientes fieles. 
Para más adelante quiere ampliar su negocio y convertirlo en un minimarket donde pueda ofrecer toda clase de productos a sus clientes.

Este es su 3er crédito con MFP, ella es parte de un banco comunal y le gusta trabajar con su grupo porque todos son responsables y trabajadores. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará más abarrotes, comestibles de primera necesidad y bebidas gaseosas para surtir su negocio.
texts.en:
Luz is 22 years old. She has a 9-month baby boy and lives with her common-law husband, who’s a free lance worker, and with her sister in the house she owns. Two years ago, she opened a small shop at home, where she sells groceries, basic food products and soft drinks. Luz works at the shop all day. She has a very successful business because she's located in a very busy area. What she likes the most about her job is to provide a good service for her customers. She also likes to feel active, which is very important to her. At the same time, her business is very profitable because she sells items every day to regular customers. In the future, she would like to expand her business and turn it into a minimarket where she can offer all kinds of products to her customers. This is her 3rd loan with MFP. She’s a member of a community bank and she likes to work with her group because they’re all responsible hard workers. With the money she’s requesting, she will buy more groceries, basic food items and soft drinks to restock her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Restock her business

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
La Sra. Francisca H.  tiene 63 años de edad,  con tres hijos,  que ya son mayores de edad  todos casados, hace 6 meses falleció su marido, pero de igual manera queda acargo de su negocio por lo que  tiene que solventar los gastos familiares ella sola. 
Ella  cuenta que la casa donde viven actualmente, le había regalado su tía , comentó también que   hace 16 años atrás  se dedica a la venta de ropas, cosméticos y otros. 
En la comunidad, era la única tienda que se encontraba en aquella época. 
Desde su inicio el negocio sigue ubicada en el mismo lugar, se ha convertido en el centro más importante de compras de prendas de todo tipo, por el buen precio, la buena ubicación del negocio y la excelente atención de la propia dueña. 
Según nos manifiesta  gracias al primer crédito que se le otorgo de la Fundación Pya  pudo agrandar su negocio y asi seguir adelante. 
El crédito solicitado consistirá en compra de cosméticos y prenda de la temporada (: cremas faciales, desodorantes, maquillajes, bronceadores, entre otros) para poder brindar una buena atención a su clientela.
texts.en:
Señora Francisca H. is 63-years-old and has 3 children who are all adults and married. Her husband passed away 6 months ago, but she is still running her business because she now has to pay for their home's expenses alone. She owns the house where she currently lives. Her aunt gave it to her. She has sold clothing, cosmetics, and other items for 16 years. Hers was the only store of this kind that was available back then. Her business has been located in the same place since she started. It has become an important place for shopping for all types of clothing at a good price, in a good location, with excellent service from the owner. She is thankful for the first loan that Fundación Paraguaya offered her so she could grow her business. She will use the requested credit to purchase cosmetics and seasonal clothing (facial cream, deodorant, makeup, bronzers, etc) to be able to offer complete service to her clientele.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and clothing (facial cream, perfume, deodorant, makeup, t-shirts, pants, etc.)

loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
Leng S., 34, is married and lives with her six children in Siem Reap Town, Cambodia. Leng S. grows vegetables and also goes fishing. She is able to earn an income of US$1.50 per day to help cover the family expenses. She has been in these businesses since 2000. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of US$5.50 per day.

Leng S. and her family members try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. They are seeking to improve their businesses as well. As a result, S. is requesting a loan of US$1,200 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the loan to purchase more farmland to grow more produce for sale. This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy more farmland to grow more vegetables

loans.name: Aura Elena

texts.es:
La actividad de esta señora Aura Guardián consiste en la venta de granos básicos como maíz, frijoles, sorgo, los cuales los adquiere en las diferentes comarcas del municipio de El Sauce para venderlos a los dueños de las pulpería al por mayor vendidos en sacos grandes.
Actualmente ella atraviesa la necesidad de invertir en la compra de los granos básicos y es por este motivo que está solicitando un crédito para adquirirlos y así continuar comercializándolos para obtener los ingresos de su hogar y así bendecir a su familia con el sustento de cada día.
texts.en:
Aura Guardián’s activity consists of selling basic grains like corn, beans, and sorghum. She gets them in different regions in the El Sauce municipality. She sells them wholesale in large sacks to the owners of the mini-markets. She currently needs to invest in the purchase of basic grains. That is why she is asking for a loan to get them and continue selling them. This is to get income for her home and to bless her family with their daily sustenance.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy basic grains

loans.name: We Will Do It Group

texts.en:
Christina O. is the leader of group five borrowers called "We Will Do It." She is 35 years old, married with four children between the ages of 4 and 15 years old  — nursery school to 5th grade. Christina, who is shown on the right holding the sign, could not continue her own education past 4th grade due to poverty. 

Her business is the sale of foodstuffs such as salt, pepper, oil, and seasonings  She buys her goods wholesale and sells retail on a table in the Red Light Market, which is the largest market in Liberia  She has been running her business for four years and hopes to grow it into a store in the near future.

Christina started by selling cold water with a small amount of money, but later added foodstuffs. She positions her goods on her table in an attractive way so that customers are interested in buying from her. Christina will use this loan to purchase additional salt, onions, pepper and seasonings for resale. She dreams of giving her children a good education and building a house for her family.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional salt, onions, pepper and seasonings for resale.

loans.name: Maisaa

texts.en:
Maisaa is a 20-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with her husband. Maisaa has been selling perfumes. She actually has the perfume fragrances and sometimes (depending on her client’s wishes) she makes combinations. Her clients are her friends and neighbors, and sometimes people from the surrounding villages. 

When she first started her business, she had some financial issues. She decided on doing her business because she wanted to supplement her family’s income and have an independent job; she came up with her shop idea since she is the only one in her region doing this, and she felt before opening her shop that this was a much-demanded product. 

She requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase perfumes for the summer season--more fruity smells and less strong than those for winter. This is the first time that Maisaa has requested a loan from Al Majmoua. In the future, she plans on expanding her work.

loans.use: To purchase perfumes for the summer season

loans.name: Oleg

texts.en:
Oleg is married and has two teenage daughters. He sells bicycles, spare parts, and other cycle supplies at the hardware market in Berdyansk. He has been in this business for 13 years and just likes selling bicycles. Besides good products, Oleg offers his customers bicycle maintenance services. People value this kind of service and recommend Oleg to their friends.
Oleg has used business loans before and finds them instrumental in developing his business. Prompt loan repayment and self-discipline have characterized Oleg in the past. This time, Oleg is requesting a loan of 20,000 UAH to increase his inventory of bicycles and various components. Financial assistance will continue to promote the growth of his business and give many bike-lovers the extra moments of joy, speed and adventure that come with riding.

loans.use: To purchase bicycles and components for resale

loans.name: Chhuorn's Group

texts.en:
Seventeen people, who are all living in Dei Edth Kaoh Phos village in Kandal province, make up this village bank loan. The members will each use the loan for a different purpose.

Mr. Chhuorn R. is 57 years old and he is the village bank president who has selected by the members. He and his wife, Mrs. Saroeun Koet, are pig breeders and also rice-wine makers who are able to earn a small income to support their family.

Since their pig business is going well, they want to expand it. Thus, Mr. Chhuorn R. decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets to raise and sell. With this loan, he hopes to increase his income to improve his family living conditions. This couple has a child who is a student.

loans.use: To buy more piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: José Antonio

texts.es:
El señor José Antonio R. esta muy agradecido por su cooperación en el anterior crédito, el cual le ayudo a mejor su negocio. 
Es nuevamente solicitando un préstamo para comprar herramienta que le esta haciendo falta y material. Ya que en este momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario y tiene varios trabajos pendientes para entregar y no cuenta con el materia para terminar. 
Planea pagar el crédito con una parte de las ganancias del negocio y que es la fuente de ingresos del su familia.
texts.en:
Sr. José Antonio R. is grateful for the assistance from his previous loan, which helped to improve his business.

He is requesting a new loan in order to buy tools and materials that he is lacking. At the moment, he does not have the necessary funds. He has several pending jobs that needed to be completed, but he does not have the materials to finish them.

José Antonio plans to repay the loan using part of the earnings from his business, which is his family’s source of income.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tools & materials for his business

loans.name: Mr. Borin Chheang Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eleven people who live in Spean Daek village in Kandal province make up this village bank loan group. Mr. Borin C. is the village bank president, selected by all the members, who will each use their loan for different purposes so that it can improve their businesses in the future. He is a motorbike taxi driver and his wife, Mrs. Solim Soth, is a Khmer cake maker in their local village. 

Since his wife’s business is going well he wants to expand it. So to improve this business, Mr. Borin C. is seeking a loan to buy more firewood for making cakes in the raining season. He is the father of five children who are attending local public school.

loans.use: To buy more firewood for making cake

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia V. is from the village of Kilikili, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 42 years old. Virginia is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Virginia owns and operates a furniture-making business.  The main source of income for the business comes from making and selling cabinets and wardrobes to local businesses and community members. Virginia has been engaged in her business for more than 4 years and earns approximately 16,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. That loan was used to to purchase tools and other equipment to expand the business. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP to be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Virginia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional furniture

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Mrs. N. is 50 years old and resides in a rural area of Kompong Cham Province. She has a small business producing and selling skewers. She buys raw materials (bamboo) and turns them into batches of skewers for sale. By doing this, N. is able to generate an average of $2.40 a day to cover the daily expenses of her family. She is married with four children: two are now married and the other two are single.


Her husband has been operating a taxi service in the local community. Currently he faces the problem that his motor-taxi breaks down often during passenger pick-ups. To avoid this, N. decided to ask for a loan to renovate the broken taxi.

loans.use: To renovate the broken taxi.

loans.name: Kinanda Ole

texts.en:
Kinanda Ole M. is 30 years old. He is married to Mary M. and is a father of two school-going children. Kinanda is a farmer, and he has been farming his own piece of land for the last six years.

He learned about KADET through a friend who was already a registered member of KADET. This will be his first loan. He is planning to spend 20,000 on ploughing, 10,000 on harrowing, 20,000 on seeds and 10,000 on planting his 10 acres of wheat. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity by acquiring more land to increase his wheat production.

Kinanda's dream is to do large scale farming and to buy his own farm machinery. He is a hard-working man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To spend on ploughing, harrowing and seeds, and on planting his 10 acres of wheat

loans.name: Idalia Del Carmen

texts.es:
Idalia del Carmen tiene 45 años, reside en el Municipio del Tránsito, departamento de San Miguel, es madre soltera tiene dos hijos los cuales dependen económicamente de ella, se dedica a la venta de tamales y venta de ropa de forma ambulante (por las calles). 
El negocio lo emprendió por iniciativa propia, a causa de necesidad de trabajo, los hijos le ayudan también con  el negocio, ella necesita un préstamo para invertirlo en la compra de ropa: camisas, faldas, pantalones, vestidos, ropa para niños, ella está considerando vender estos productos de forma ambulante para obtener mayores ventas. Este préstamo le permitirá continuar con el negocio, satisfacer demanda de los clientes, ofreciéndole estilos nuevos de ropa, mejorar los ingresos.
El sueños es crecer los negocios apoyar a los dos hijos, brindarle una estabilidad económica.
texts.en:
Idalia del Carmen is 45 years old and lives in the town of Tránsito, located in the San Miguel department. She is a single mother with two children who depend on her for support. She sells tamales and clothing on foot. She began this business by her own initiative because she needed work and her children help her with the business. She needs a loan in order to invest in clothing: shirts, skirts, pants, dresses, children’s clothing. She is considering selling these items on foot in order to obtain better sales. This loan will allow her to continue her business, satisfy her customer demand, offer new styles of clothing, and increase her income. She hopes to grow her business, support her children, and provide economic stability for them.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Clothing for resale

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 45 years old, married and has two children. He graduated from intermediate school. 

The borrower will use this loan to develop his carpentry shop and purchase a sawing machine and wood. The borrower has been working in this field for five years and gained lots of experience and expertise. Because he does a good job, he has many clients. The borrower has a good reputation in the market.

loans.use: To buy a sawing machine and wood

loans.name: Doraliza

texts.en: Doraliza A. is from the village of Benhaan, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 32 years old and is married with three school-aged children. Doraliza owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies and also running a mini-store in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Doraliza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Doraliza plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Huyen

texts.en: Huyen T. D. is 28 years old and has two small children. Ms. Huyen has a workshop that makes wood products, such as tables and desks, on customer order. She has run this kind of business for six years. Since joining the credit program, she has used her loans effectively and repaid very well. She is now requesting a loan of 9,810,000 Vietnamese Dong (VND) to buy material for her workshop.

loans.use: To buy material for her workshop

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita E., 46 years old, is married with two children and is a member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) partner Microfinance Institution of KIVA in the Philippines. She joined ASHI in 1995 and today she is one of the many loyal and active members of the institution.

 As a member, she is known for being a disciplined and responsible person especially when it comes to helping other members. The primary source of income of her family is farming. The family works hand in hand in tilling their land and planting rice and vegetables. Profit from this business helps the couple in paying the school expenses of their daughter and son. They are able to provide for the daily needs of the family.

 It is rice-planting season again, and that is why she is applying for a loan of Php.30,000 for land preparation. The couple will buy vegetable seeds, sacks of organic fertilizers, pesticides and pay for farm labor. Additional income from this business will be of great help for the schooling and daily expenses of the family. 

The couple wish their children to pursue a degree in college and have a stable job in the future. They also have started renovating their house and hope to complete it once they have earned profit from this business. Their goal in life is to expand their rice and vegetable farming business and establish income for their future. Merlita is thankful that ASHI and KIVA are here to support and assist them financially in fulfilling her dreams for her family.

loans.use: To buy rice and vegetable seeds, fertilizer, pesticides and pay for labor

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann W. is 25 years old and a single lady. She has managed a general store for about two years at Zambezi, Nderi in Kikuyu. Most of her clients are residents in that area. She earns a profit of Kshs. 18,000 per month, and her other source of income is through farming.

She has no history with any other microfinance institution (MFI). She was introduced to KADET LTD by Francis Ndungu who is the chairman of an existing group of KADET. She is applying for her third loan of Kshs. 40,000 to add more stock to the general store and also she plans to diversify her business with the income generated.
 
Ann hopes to establish a wholesale cosmetic and general products shop in Zambezi so that she can cater for her educational needs as she aspires to going back to school.

loans.use: To buy more stock for the business

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en:
Hoa K., 38, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. K. sells brooms, earning an income of $2 per day. Her husband is a carpenter, earning an income of about $4 per day. The family has to spend $45 on food, $5 on electricity supply and $25 on other necessary expenses every month. 

K. is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Armen

texts.en:
Armen A. is 29 years old. He is married and lives in Tsovaghugh village in the Sevan area with his wife and his 1-year-old baby.

Armen is a mechanical engineer, but he manages his own business: spare parts for cars. In the near future, Armen will become a father for the second time, so he intends to increase his family’s income thanks to his business development. 

To achieve his goal, Armen asks for a 800,000 Armenian drams loan, which will allow him to adapt and repair part of his shop for a household goods trading organization and to buy merchandise for it.

loans.use: To adapt and repair part of his shop for a household goods trading organization and to buy merchandise for it

loans.name: Noemi

texts.en:
Noemi is 22 years old. She lives with her husband and their 3-year-old daughter. It is a very loving and happy home and they have great attitude and excitement to improve their lives. They live in the sector of San Salvador in the district of Paijan, approximately forty minutes outside of the city of Trujillo. They own their home and live in an urban zone.

Noemi sells beauty products of the Eskia brand. She has been running her business for a number of years and she has a solid client base. She sells products both on credit and on request. She also maintains a small inventory so that she can make immediate sales to new clients. Her clients appreciate her high level of customer service and flexible terms. Noemi’s husband has a stable job in the city.

This will be Noemi’s first loan with Edpyme Alternativa. She plans to use the loan to purchase additional inventory in order to better serve her clients during the holiday season. She also plans to use a portion of the funds to meet a few personal expenses for her home and to improve her family’s quality of life. Noemi is proud to be a solid income source for her family and to be maintaining her own business.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Jamirah

texts.en:
Jamirah N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is married and has 1 child who is currently in school. Jamirah has been operating a business selling food and vegetables for 1 year.         

To help expand her business, Jamirah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase food.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Jamirah hopes to generate greater profits and to take care of herself. In the future, Jamirah hopes to own a retail shop.        

Jamirah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her improve on her business.

loans.use: to buy food

loans.name: Randy

texts.en:
Randy S. is from the village of Nailon Tudela Misamis Occidental. He is 37 years old. Randy is married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Randy owns and operates a passenger van service. Randy has had his business for over two years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Randy joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and business. Randy has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC. Randy is requesting a new loan of 12800 PHP which will be used to repair his passenger van for better service. This will be his second loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue to improve his family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units of offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair his existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Justina

texts.es:
Justina es socia del Banco Comunal “3 de Mayo II”  del distrito Puno,  provincia de Puno y departamento de Puno, tiene 39 años de edad, de estado civil casada y tiene 03 hijos (02 independientes), la señora realizo estudios de educación primaria.

Trabaja con  el Movimiento  Manuela  Ramos desde hace 02 años,  su  préstamo  inicial fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, dinero que utilizo para incrementar el capital de su negocio de venta al por menor de ropas para niños.

Su nuevo crédito es de S/. 700.00 nuevos soles, con la que podrá comprar ropas para niños de primera y segunda mano, sus hijos trabajan junto con su padre en la empresa Cocacola como chofer.

Su visión en el negocio es ser mayorista de abarrotes.

Lo que le gusta de su Banco Comunal es la unión y lo que gana el ahorro.
texts.en:
Justina is a member of the “3 de Mayo II” Communal Bank in the district of Puno, province of Puno and department of Puno. She is 39 years old, married and has 3 children (2 independent). She has completed elementary education.

She has worked with Movimiento Manuela Ramos for 2 years. Her first loan was for 300.00 Nuevos Soles, money which she used to increase capital for her business selling first and second-hand children’s clothing. Her children work with her husband for the Cocacola business as drivers.

Her business vision is to be a wholesaler of groceries.

What she likes about her Communal Bank is the union and what she gains from saving.

loans.use: To purchase and sell children clothing

loans.name: Gulomjon

texts.en:
